title: When will the FDA and/or CDC recommend that at least some Americans fully vaccinated for COVID-19 receive a COVID-19 vaccine booster shot?
preds: FDA approved 12-AUG:  https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/coronavirus-covid-19-update-fda-authorizes-additional-vaccine-dose-certain-immunocompromised "Today, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration amended the emergency use authorizations (EUAs) for both the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 Vaccine and the Moderna COVID-19 Vaccine to allow for the use of an additional dose in certain immunocompromised individuals, specifically, solid organ transplant recipients or those who are diagnosed with conditions that are considered to have an equivalent level of immunocompromise."

Not a dead-cert yet, but the FDA approval seems like another very strong indicator, justifying a further shift in probability. Despite looking, I struggle to find any compelling reason that a recommendation might not be made - the only reasonable counter-argument is that vaccines should be distributed to other countries in need first before boosters. There appears to be little domestic appetite for this approach. Frankly, I give very strong odds of a recommendation by the 15th August!

Thanks to news from @Emking on the meeting Friday I dramatically increased the chance of this happening before 9/1.  The base case was always to move at about the speed of the EUA. For the original EUA data was released November 9th, meeting was December 10th, and approval was December 11th. I noted this in my first prediction but didn't have the guts to give more likelihood to August, but here we are.  We got data on the booster on July 8th. The meeting will be August 13th. Given past timing, not much logic for the recommendation to not be made before 9/1. I think there is some chance of a delayed 'shot in arms' based on pressure from WHO etc..., but we'll at least be giving to immunocompromised people, and, either way, this is based on recommendation not shot in arms. See, for example, this article saying FDA plans to have a booster strategy in September, seemingly recommendation would have to be sooner. https://www.healthline.com/health-news/should-immunocompromised-people-get-booster-shots-what-the-experts-say#The-bottom-line

The CDC advisory panel is meeting on 13th August to discussion booster shots - https://www.reuters.com/business/healthcare-pharmaceuticals/us-cdc-advisers-review-data-covid-19-vaccine-boosters-2021-08-09/ Given roll-out in Israel and a number of other countries with similar medical methodologies and the strong support of Dr Fauci, I'm significantly increasing the probability of an August roll-out - especially (as previously mentioned) the question is specifically on when a recommendation is made, rather than when the boosters would be given.  The latest Delta wave is likely to sharpen thinking, especially given the lag effects (for both doses and effectiveness).

- This morning, all the media outlets are pushing their prepared headline "At least 1 million people got unauthorized 3rd booster shot: CDC." (https://abc7.com/unauthorized-booster-shots-third-covid-vaccine-shot-pfizer-moderna/10944718/)
- Fauci deftly stating they don't know efficacy timeline resulting in people researching and self-prescribing (in this case the right treatment - the jab!)  (https://www.msn.com/en-us/health/medical/ahead-of-official-vaccine-guidance-some-americans-are-already-caught-up-in-booster-mania/ar-AANbU01)  Since people are getting the booster already - US can’t message that they shouldn't get one.  Very convenient chatter for Pfizer/Moderna.   
- It is also very convenient to have the CEO of Reuters as a board member if you are Pfizer.  Control the messaging.  (https://www.pfizer.com/people/leadership/board-of-directors/james_smith)  WHO matters now? (https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/french-president-macron-third-covid-vaccine-doses-likely-elderly-vulnerable-2021-08-05/)
- International proof point of strategic campaign.  Note price of vaccine going up. (https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/coronavirus/government-orders-35m-pfizer-vaccines-for-2022-booster-campaign/ar-AANcg46) The window is shortening, but I'm increasing chances of August approval announcement.

Israel's case numbers among booster vs vaccinated are very promising and I'm now adjusting to an announcement certainly coming in the next few months for immunocompromised and likely >60 population (which would resolve YES for the question).  Again, would rather weight the front month heavier prior to the public comments tomorrow.

Note from @Emking has me flipping back to weighting heavily towards pre-Sep announcement.  if you look at the messaging playbook here (https://jhsphcenterforhealthsecurity.s3.amazonaws.com/spars-pandemic-scenario.pdf) quick response that is empathetic and addresses the concerns of specific audiences is important.  International response approaches matter too.  (Think Israel.)
Thanks to the link from @Emking , looks like there's a chance they recommend on Friday, will hold here until we see what happens Friday.

Based on @Emking comment below I will up my Before September 1st until the 13th and review the public comments from the meeting so I don't get burned on a surprise announcement.  Still expecting that they will not recommend fully for another few weeks at least.

Additionally, I note the criterion that this resolves when the recommendation is made rather than when it is recommended the doses start to be issued. Israel is already well under way and considering expanding the age cohort and as US new cases are back at February levels, there seems a much stronger case that a recommendation to provide boosters to the most vulnerable will be made in a tighter timeframe than I previously thought.

Both Moderna and Pfizer agree that boosters are needed before winter and within 12 months of the first dose, respectfully. As brought up by some users here, doing it soon will help with liability issues (though goes against WHO's preferred plan of action). Since it will take a few months for a bulk of Americans to get the booster by the December deadline of 12 months since the first dose was issued, then it is urgent that they begin around September. I increase confidence through August due to what seems like bias from experts that it could be approved sooner, for the key word in this question is SOME Americans. It means not majority but any group of Americans. It is reasonable that the very vulnerable can get the first approval and more approvals can come forth down the timeline.

The UK is planning to offer boosters: https://www.reuters.com/world/uk/britain-offer-vaccine-booster-shots-32-million-next-month-the-telegraph-2021-08-01/ I suspect the US will follow suit, which may take about a month to get rolling - but there's a chance the CDC will not recommend it at all, because honestly the CDC has been careening wildly through this pandemic and who's to say.

Shifting up the timeline a bit based on experience of UK, Japan and Israel. If the arc of delta in the UK is at all indicative, US is about a month behind and there will be enormous pressure to “do something”. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-08-01/fauci-backs-vaccines-u-k-plans-booster-shots-virus-update?srnd=premium&sref=i2Bc5OtW

Several countries with greater vaccinations rates than the US have already announced plans to provide booster shots (e.g., UK, Israel) because of the already existing Delta variant that has a non-negligible probability of infecting fully vaccinated people, in particular when there is still a large amount of unvaccinated adults and children and a high enough infection rate in the population as a whole that makes it likely for fully vaccinated adults to come into contact with an infected person. The US has access to a large enough supply of vaccines for booster shots to be practical to provide, and the medical evidence seems to be that booster shots would be safe and effective, even when mixing different vaccines. Thus as countries such as the UK move forward with booster shots starting in September (per published UK government plans), it seems reasonable to expect the FDA and/or the CDC to announce a similar program. I also believe this may be motivated by public demand. The uncertainty for me is more about how fast the CDC and/or the FDA will move. If this does not happen before November, at which point the Delta variant may have passed its peak, then it is more likely to happen later in the event of a new variant that is even more infectious for fully vaccinated people.

If the vaccinations don’t pick back up and the Delta variant continues to spread rapidly into September and October, there’s a chance the FDA would recommend booster shots for individuals who travel for work. This will definitely happen after Jan 1 in 2022 as new variants may arise.
I believe the decision will be motivated by supply.
There is only about 9 mil people in the immunocompromised group. So this isn't taking bulk vaccines from the rest of the world.
Many people who were among first to be vaxxed will approach the one year mark in December.

Right now it's clear the data supports that this will be approved. Trials in Israel + data from Pfizer show good results, especially for immunocompromised populations. But this is a public health decision. The question is timing.  Base Case:
* During the initial vaccine Pfizer released data on November 9th and we didn't have the EUA until December 11th, just over 1 month at an extremely critical time to save lives. For the booster, Pfizer released data on July 8th and stated they submit early August. ~August 10th seems to be the exact comp, pretty close to the September 1 date. Anytime after November 1 seems extremely unlikely. It would have to be delayed for months longer than we've seen.  Ideas in support of before 9/1:
1) If timeline was similar to prior FDA work it would seem likely to fall in August. This is the strongest piece of info I think we have.
2) Framing of the question would seem to support CDC/FDA approval for just immunocompromised people - like cancer survivors and transplant recipients. Data seems to strongly suggest these populations need boosters. I could imagine pressure for this group working separately than a broader approval for elderly/everyone Thoughts in favor of after 9/1
1) Surgeon General just stated "you don't need to go out and get a booster shot". Feels like a whipsaw to then approve it within 1 month
2) FDA is just balancing more questions than it was before. Should they do a full approval (more important for getting everyone vaccinated), approve for kids (important for schools opening), etc.... The prior timeline was when it was the most important question before them. 
3) This Booster is not targeted at Delta. Pfizer is separately doing clinical trials for a Delta specific booster. Given the virility of Delta I wonder if there will be pressure to wait for data from that trial
4) Public health officials are very focused on getting more unvaccinated people vaccinated. Most competition for vaccines could make that harder. 
5) US using more vaccines internally means fewer shots for the rest of the world. Optics issue with foreign policy + ethical ramifications. I don't think this will stop approval, but I could see it impacting timeline. Ultimately I think that the timing and politics makes it challenging to get done before 9/1

I requested clarification and would welcome input from those who understand the FDA approval process:  *What counts as recommendation of a "Booster" ? *
1) A "booster" is "An additional dose of a vaccine needed periodically to 'boost' the immune system." As I understand it, this is a distinct type of FDA approval. Importantly, approval for a "booster" grants permission to use the vaccine on a periodic basis (e.g. every 10 years for tetanus boosters).  2) Alternatively, Pharma companies may apply for a change to their emergency use authorizations for their COVID vaccines, such as to change their vaccine from a two-dose to a three-dose label. It that happens, the 3rd dose isn't a "booster", it's a 3rd dose. [Think about it this way: the 2nd dose of Pfizer isn't a booster; it's a second dose.] Either of the above will likely be referred to as "boosters" in the press, confusing matters.  *What about "fully vaccinated"? *
Here's another issue: If the FDA changes the authorization of Pfizer (for example) to a 3-dose label, or the CDC makes a 3rd dose recommended for some people, then they have also changed the definition of what "fully vaccinated" means. People can get a 3rd does, but now they aren't "fully vaccinated" until after they received the 3rd dose.  So my question is: Should this question resolve as "Yes" or "No" if the CDC recommends a third dose but without specifying that it's a booster?

This is an interesting question.  First, I'll say that it seems certain that boosters will be necessary, so the question in my mind is "when?", not if. However the timing is far from clear to me. From a practical standpoint I think a lot of Americans have or will soon realize that they will have better protection with a third (or second depending on the vaccine) shot. There is also some ambiguity in the question: would changing Pfizer's approval from a 2-dose to a 3-dose regime count as a "booster". I would say "no" from a scientific standpoint but who knows how the GJOpen folks would score that. I'll ask. Apparently, increasing the doses is more likely in the short run than approving a booster. For the shorter buckets, I think the issues are practical and public-health oriented (i.e. political). Factors that will affect timing: 
1) for one of the major vaccines to get approved: application submitted by vaccine maker + time to approve. Fauci: “We’re a long way from that.” [1] I'm going to say that's >3 months
2) the wild card here is approval of a delta-variant-specific booster. That scenario could be fast, and at least one is in trials. [1]
3) "Deciding to add a third shot to the Pfizer series comes with all sorts of other opportunity costs, too — including further delaying access to vaccine for low- and middle-income countries. " => I don't know how much this will affect the thinking of US health officials. My guess is that it will only to the extent that they believe that it will affect the expected health outcomes of Americans. I believe that at the margin, that will cause them to err a little on the side of waiting.
4) How much will news of delta variant spike put political pressure on the FDA to act? I'm not sure, but in the past they have appeared to largely ignore political pressure. 
5) there will be a wave of people who were vaccinated in Mar - May who will have waning immunity by around 6 months later (Sep - Nov) and those folks will start getting COVID in larger numbers and with greater severity. That will put some real pressure on the system to move. 
6) finally, I think there's a bit of wishful thinking here. I’m sure many forecasters would love for boosters to be approved sooner ... because it makes scientific sense and because they want to be protected and protect their loved ones. Unfortunately I think it will take longer.  My take on all of this is that the short bucket is unlikely and I'm split between Sept - Dec. [1] https://www.statnews.com/2021/07/12/when-and-how-will-we-know-covid-19-booster-shots/

An expert advisory panel says it can’t recommend booster shots for patients with compromised immune systems until the FDA updates its authorization for Covid-19 vaccines or fully approves the shots. Dearth of data: People with compromised immune systems resulting from advanced or untreated HIV, organ transplant recipients or certain cancer treatments have lower antibody protection from Covid-19 vaccines, and these individuals tend to get more severe cases of Covid-19. But so far, clinical trials have only featured dozens of these patients — which is not enough yet for FDA to update its emergency use authorizations. These studies are ongoing. What FDA says: “FDA is working as rapidly as possible to conduct a thorough and comprehensive review of all regulatory submissions for Covid-19 vaccines with the goal of ultimately approving safe and effective Covid-19 vaccines for use in the US,” said Doran Fink, a deputy director of the agency's division of vaccines and related products. He added that FDA is also exploring all possible regulatory routes that could provide additional access to vaccines in situations where data suggests that benefits outweigh the risks. https://www.politico.com/newsletters/prescription-pulse/2021/07/23/cdc-advisers-hold-off-on-covid-booster-shot-call-796674

According to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Booster_dose, there are relatively few booster vaccines. Perhaps the best comparison to a COVID booster would be to yearly flu shots.  Recent news states that "On Thursday, a key official at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said the agency is exploring options to give patients with compromised immune systems third doses even before regulators broaden the emergency use authorization for coronavirus vaccines, a step that could come soon for the Pfizer vaccine" (https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/23/us/covid-vaccine-boosters.html). Furthermore, there has been data from Israel's Public Health Ministry that states that certain vaccines are relatively ineffective against the Delta variant (39% VE), which may signal a greater need for boosters. However, this should also be considered in context with contrasting UK studies. I think that there is a significant chance that a booster is approved in the coming month, especially with the CDC and White House commenting on the matter.

In the absence of considerations for immunocompromised people I would probably be at 55% in the last bucket. The vaccines have continued to show strong protection against variants, though slightly reduced. However, immunocompromised people throws a wrench into things, as other commenters have pointed out. I think though that there's a decent chance the FDA and CDC may not officially recommend immunocompromised people get a third shot without further study. [1] and [2] are informative on this. Especially the following quote from [2]: "...the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices cannot recommend that until the Food and Drug Administration gives full approval to the currently available vaccines or amends its emergency use authorization. The FDA’s existing authorization permits only a two-dose regimen of the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines, or a single dose of the Johnson & Johnson product." But there may be ways around that. Again from [2]: "Amanda Cohn, the CDC’s chief medical officer for vaccine policy, said the agency is exploring options to make additional doses possible for such patients. 'I think what you’re asking about is, you know, is there a way to offer a third dose to individuals … through a study, or through an investigational new drug format for this population? I will just say that we are actively looking into ways that could be done to potentially provide access earlier than any potential change in regulatory decisions,' Cohn told panel members." So the first part of that, a study, would be slow. The CDC and FDA are generally cautious (too cautious in my opinion as they've demonstrated throughout the pandemic), so it's a definite possibility they go that route. But if they took option two and did an investigational new drug format that could be pretty fast. And there's precedent for that as well. In 2013 the CDC recommended use of an unapproved vaccine at Princeton university due to a meningococcal outbreak [3]. If the above doesn't happen or they opt for a slower approach through a study, I think a booster shot recommendation is pretty unlikely by the end of the year. I think the most likely scenario would be that they recommend a second dose of Johnson and Johnson, or even an mRNA booster for J&J because J&J is the least effective of the three approved (and my impression is that it's less effective by a decent margin). One factor in this is that recommending a booster makes the vaccine hesitant even less likely to want the vaccine. That would just reinforce the misconception among the hesitant that the vaccines aren't effective or that it's futile to get the vaccine because you'll just need another dose every 6 months and then people associate it with the much less effective flu vaccine. Overall I'm giving a 75% chance of a booster recommendation by the end of the year primarily due to the potential for a recommendation specifically for immunocompromised people.
